awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Variable Circumstellar Disks: Prevalence, Timescales, and Physical Mechanisms
awd_abstract_narration:
Stars many times more massive than our Sun are rare, but they are responsible for producing nearly all of the heavier elements found in nature.  Through dramatic supernova explosions, they produce and shed this material throughout the galaxy, mixing it with material out of which the next generation of stars, and planets, are formed.  One interesting class of stars, known as Be stars, rotate so rapidly that they somehow shed material that then forms in a disk around their equators.  In order to better understand how these disks are formed and why they occasionally seem to disappear, researchers at the University of Oklahoma, Lowell Observatory, and the University of Toledo have formed a team to carry out an intensive study of these systems.  They will use an array of ground-based telescopes to observe these events, and they are developing sophisticated computer codes to aid the interpretation of these observations.  This program will support graduate students at the University of Oklahoma and at the University of Toledo, as well as undergraduate students at all three institutions.  They will develop research-based planetarium shows that satisfy state education standards. Undergraduates will be trained to develop content and conduct outreach and to take these shows on the road to K-12 students using a portable planetarium and a digital projector.  These shows will be freely released for use in other settings.

This program will determine the timescales, relative prevalence, and physical mechanisms of disk-loss and disk rebuilding episodes of classical Be stars. These goals will be accomplished by carrying out a statistical assessment of the prevalence of disk-loss/renewal episodes of populations of Be stars in open clusters, as well as intensive multi wavelength studies of individual Be stars actively experiencing disk-loss/renewal episodes. Predictions of state-of-the-art radiation transfer and hydrodynamical modeling codes will be compared against the data obtained in this program, to test a range of scenarios that have been proposed to explain how circumstellar disks may be created and destroyed during the lifetime of the host star.

por.por_cntn:
Some rapidly rotating hot, massive B-type stars develop gaseous disks around their equator during their lifetimes.  These stars are known as "Be stars" because they show bright emission lines in their spectra originating in the disks.  In some cases, these disks may dissipate and then redevelop over time, as can be inferred from the disappearance and redevelopment of the emission lines.  The physical causes for the disk formation and dissipation and the timescales over which these changes can happen are poorly understood. The goals of this project were twofold:  1) to investigate the timescales over which disk variation happens through the collection of ongoing observational diagnostics of several selected star systems, and 2) to develop theoretical and computational models and methods to help analyze and interpret the observational data in terms of possible physical causes.

The disks around the Be stars are built up by a series of outbursts or eruptions that eject material from the star.  Our observations show that the timing of these ejections is not regular or predictable.  At times it may be as short as a few days or weeks between outbursts, while at other times the star may be quiet for months or years before the next outburst.   Sporadic injection of material from the star spreads out to form the disk. We find that more luminous stars tend to be more sporadic when injecting material, while fainter stars have a somewhat smoother process.  

We find evidence that most Be stars likely have a companion star orbiting around them.  This supports the idea that Be stars rotate so rapidly because in earlier stages of the pair's lifetime, the companion star transferred much of its material onto the primary star, causing the primary star to spin-up up its rotation – up to the point where it can barely hold itself together.  As a consequence, some mechanism creates sporadic eruptions from the surface of the rapidly spinning star that throws material into orbit, creating the Be disk.  As the disk grows outward, the companion star raise "tides" in the disk, producing the two spiral arms shown in the simulation.   When material reaches the edge of the disk, it then falls toward the companion, spiraling inward and forming a second disk around the companion star.  Thus our work shows that the complete Be star system actually consists of two disks orbiting each other with a star in the center of each disk.  Interestingly, we also find that not all the material falls onto the companion star; rather, some of the material escapes and continues outward, producing the pinwheel pattern seen in the simulation of the disk (similar to the effect of a rotating garden sprinkler).

The primary scientific tools from the project include: 1) enhanced theoretical computer simulation models for studying Be star disks (a Monte Carlo Radiative Transfer codes, and a Smoothed Particle Hydrodynamics simulation code), which are available to any researchers wishing to use it; 2) a robust set of observational data which are available for ongoing observational studies; and 3) a series of published results which present our findings and lay the groundwork for future additional investigations.

A number of undergraduate students, graduate students, and postdoctoral researchers were involved in this project. They represented a diverse population, helping to develop broader representation within the science community.  During the project, they received training in observational and theoretical techniques and experience with scientific programming methods, data calibration, data reduction and analysis, and statistical methods. By presenting results through written scientific articles and papers, oral presentations, and scientific talks, they also developed skills and experience in science communication. In addition, several public talks were given to general audiences describing the project and results in an understandable way in order to share the results with the broader community.
